text: A patient presents with a fracture of the right mandibular condyle. When opening the mouth, to which side will the mandible deviate?
option4: Alternating deviation with each opening attempt
explanation:
Mandibular Deviation After Condylar Fracture

During mouth opening, both condyles normally translate forward and downward along the articular eminences. A fractured condyle cannot move properly due to mechanical obstruction or pain.

As a result, the contralateral condyle moves normally while the fractured side remains restricted, causing the mandible to deviate toward the fractured side upon opening.

Summary of patterns:
- Condylar fracture or ankylosis ‚Üí deviation toward affected side
- Lateral pterygoid spasm or hyperactivity ‚Üí deviation away from affected side

High-yield recap:
- Deviation toward fractured/restricted side
- Due to limited condylar translation on that side
- Common finding in unilateral condylar fractures

text: A 27-year-old patient presents 3 days after extraction of the mandibular third molar with severe pain radiating to the ear and a foul odor. On examination, the socket is empty with exposed bone and no blood clot. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this condition?
option1: Bacterial infection leading to acute osteomyelitis
option2: Dislodgement of the blood clot due to negative pressure
option3: Premature fibrinolysis of the blood clot within the socket
option4: Secondary intention healing with delayed granulation tissue
explanation:
Alveolar Osteitis (Dry Socket)

Alveolar osteitis is a painful post-extraction complication that occurs when the blood clot is lost or lysed prematurely. The exposed alveolar bone becomes inflamed and extremely sensitive, usually developing 2‚Äì4 days post-extraction, most often in the mandibular third molar area.

The pathophysiology involves fibrinolysis of the blood clot by the enzyme plasmin, leading to clot disintegration and bone exposure. It is not a true infection but an inflammatory process often secondarily colonized by bacteria.

Predisposing factors: difficult extraction, smoking, oral contraceptives, and poor irrigation.

Management: irrigation with saline or chlorhexidine, medicated eugenol dressing, and analgesics ‚Äî antibiotics are not indicated unless infection is suspected.

High-yield recap:
- Cause: premature fibrinolysis of clot
- Timing: 2‚Äì4 days post-extraction
- Common site: mandibular third molars
- Treatment: local irrigation + analgesic dressing

text: A 50-year-old patient requires placement of two adjacent implants in the mandibular anterior region. What is the minimum recommended distance between the two implant fixtures to preserve the interimplant bone crest?
explanation:
Interimplant Spacing

To maintain the interimplant bone crest and papilla, a minimum of 3 mm should separate adjacent implant fixtures. Placing implants closer than this (<2 mm) risks overlapping bone remodeling zones, leading to crestal bone loss and papilla loss.

Other key measurements:
- Implant‚Äìtooth distance: 1.5‚Äì2 mm
- Implant‚Äìimplant distance: 3 mm

These clearances preserve the vascular supply and support soft tissue stability between adjacent restorations.

text: When planning implant placement in the mandibular molar region, what is the minimum safety distance that should be maintained from the superior border of the inferior alveolar nerve canal?
explanation:
Implant‚ÄìVital Structure Clearance

A minimum 2 mm safety zone must be maintained between the apex of an implant and the superior border of the inferior alveolar canal (IAC) to avoid nerve damage. This accounts for drilling tolerance and natural remodeling.

Additional guidelines:
- Mental foramen: maintain at least 5 mm anterior clearance
- Maxillary sinus: at least 1 mm clearance, or sinus lift if inadequate
- Buccal/lingual bone: at least 1 mm on each side for cortical support

High-yield recap:
- IAC: 2 mm clearance
- Mental foramen: 5 mm anterior
- Sinus: ‚â•1 mm clearance
- Buccal/lingual wall: ‚â•1 mm each side

text: A CBCT scan shows that a patient has 2 mm of buccal bone and 1 mm of lingual bone at the intended implant site. What should be the minimum bone thickness surrounding an implant to ensure long-term success?
option2: 1 mm on both buccal and lingual sides
option4: No specific requirement if bone density is adequate
explanation:
Buccal and Lingual Bone Thickness

For optimal implant stability and esthetics, at least 1 mm of bone should remain on both buccal and lingual (or palatal) sides of the implant. Insufficient cortical thickness increases the risk of bone resorption, implant thread exposure, and soft tissue recession.

In esthetic areas such as the anterior maxilla, maintaining >1 mm buccal bone is critical to avoid gray shine-through and to preserve the gingival contour.

Rule of thumb: ridge width should equal implant diameter + 2 mm (1 mm on each side). If deficient, perform guided bone regeneration or ridge augmentation prior to implant placement.

text: A 28-year-old male presents after a motor-vehicle accident with facial elongation, bilateral periorbital ecchymosis, and mobility of the entire midface when grasped at the maxillary teeth. Which of the following best describes this injury pattern?
option1: Le Fort I fracture ‚Äî horizontal fracture separating the maxilla from the nasal floor
option2: Le Fort II fracture ‚Äî pyramidal fracture involving the nasal bridge and infraorbital rims
option3: Le Fort III fracture ‚Äî craniofacial disjunction with separation of the entire midface from the skull base
option4: Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture ‚Äî isolated fracture of the zygomatic arch and orbital rim
explanation:
Le Fort Fractures

Le Fort fractures are mid-facial fractures involving the maxilla and surrounding structures. They are classified into three horizontal planes based on severity.

Le Fort I ‚Äì 'Floating palate' (Horizontal): Runs above the apices of the teeth through the nasal floor, lateral maxillary sinus walls, and pterygoid plates, separating the alveolar process and hard palate from the face.

Le Fort II ‚Äì 'Pyramidal': Extends from the nasal bridge through the medial orbital walls and infraorbital rims to the pterygoid plates, forming a pyramidal shape. Signs: raccoon eyes, infraorbital step deformity, midface mobility.

Le Fort III ‚Äì 'Craniofacial disjunction': The most severe form, separating the entire midface from the skull base via the nasofrontal suture, orbital walls, and zygomatic arches. Signs: facial elongation, CSF rhinorrhea, airway compromise.

High-yield recap:
- Le Fort I ‚Üí Horizontal (palate)
- Le Fort II ‚Üí Pyramidal (nasal + infraorbital)
- Le Fort III ‚Üí Craniofacial disjunction
- Treatment: ORIF and airway management.

text: Cleft lip results from a failure of fusion between which of the following embryologic structures?
option1: Lateral nasal and medial nasal prominences
option2: Medial nasal and lateral palatine processes
explanation:
Cleft Lip and Palate

A cleft lip occurs due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and the maxillary prominence during weeks 4‚Äì7 of development. This fusion forms the upper lip and primary palate.

The medial nasal processes form the philtrum and premaxilla, while the maxillary processes form the upper cheeks and lateral lip. When fusion fails, a cleft lip develops‚Äîunilateral, bilateral, or rarely median if both medial nasal prominences fail to fuse.

A cleft palate occurs later (weeks 7‚Äì10) when the lateral palatine shelves fail to fuse, creating a communication between oral and nasal cavities.

Associated Syndromes:
- Van der Woude syndrome ‚Üí IRF6 mutation, lower lip pits
- Pierre Robin sequence ‚Üí micrognathia, glossoptosis, airway obstruction, U-shaped cleft palate
- Treacher Collins syndrome ‚Üí mandibulofacial dysostosis with cleft palate
- 22q11 deletion (DiGeorge/Velocardiofacial) ‚Üí cardiac defects, palatal abnormalities, thymic hypoplasia
- Holoprosencephaly ‚Üí median cleft lip with midline brain defect

High-yield recap:
- üß¨ Cleft lip: medial nasal + maxillary fusion failure (4‚Äì7 weeks)
- üß¨ Cleft palate: palatine shelf fusion failure (7‚Äì10 weeks)
- ‚öïÔ∏è Key syndromes: Van der Woude, Pierre Robin, Treacher Collins, 22q11 deletion, Holoprosencephaly
- üçº Surgical repair: around 3 months (Rule of 10s: ‚â•10 weeks, ‚â•10 lbs, Hb ‚â•10 g/dL)

text: Which salivary gland is most commonly affected by sialolith formation?
explanation:
Sialolithiasis is the formation of calcified deposits (salivary stones) within the ducts of the salivary glands. It presents clinically with intermittent swelling and pain that worsen during meals ‚Äî the classic ‚Äúmealtime syndrome.‚Äù

Most affected gland:
The submandibular gland is involved in 80‚Äì90% of cases. The parotid gland accounts for about 5‚Äì10%, while the sublingual and minor salivary glands are rarely affected.

Why the submandibular gland is most affected:
- Its excretory duct, Wharton‚Äôs duct, follows a long, tortuous, upward path that slows salivary drainage.
- Submandibular saliva is more alkaline, more mucinous, and richer in calcium and phosphate, favoring stone formation.
- The gland‚Äôs dependent position allows stasis of saliva, especially with dehydration.

Clinical features:
- Pain and swelling during meals, resolving between episodes.
- A firm nodule may be palpable in the floor of the mouth.
- Chronic obstruction can lead to sialadenitis (infection).

Diagnosis and management:
- Radiographs or ultrasound confirm the stone (most submandibular stones are radiopaque).
- Hydration, sialogogues, massage, and warm compresses aid small stone clearance.
- Sialolithotomy or sialendoscopy for persistent cases.

High-yield recap:
üßä Most common gland ‚Äî Submandibular.
‚öôÔ∏è Cause ‚Äî Thick alkaline saliva + upward duct.
üçã Symptoms ‚Äî Pain/swelling at meals.
üíä Treatment ‚Äî Hydration, sialogogues, surgery if needed.

text: A patient sustains a traumatic blow to the right side of the mandible, resulting in a fracture of the right mandibular body. Which of the following additional fractures is most likely present?
explanation:
Explanation:
The mandible acts as a ring‚Äîforce applied at one point often causes a secondary fracture at another. A blow to the right body transmits force posteriorly and across the symphysis to the contralateral side. This stress concentrates at the left condylar neck, leading to a fracture there.

High-yield recap:
- Mandible fractures commonly occur in pairs.
- Blow to body ‚Üí contralateral condyle fracture.
- Parasymphysis fracture ‚Üí contralateral condyle fracture.
- Symphyseal fracture ‚Üí bilateral condyles may fracture.

text: After a Le Fort I fracture, the primary branches of the maxillary artery are severed. Which artery continues to supply the maxilla through collateral circulation?
explanation:
Explanation:
A Le Fort I fracture separates the maxilla from the midface at the nasal floor and pterygoid plates, severing the descending palatine arteries (main supply from the maxillary artery). Collateral flow is maintained primarily by the ascending pharyngeal artery, a branch of the external carotid, which sends pharyngeal and palatine branches that anastomose with remnants of the maxillary and facial arterial networks.

High-yield recap:
‚úÖ Normal supply: descending palatine artery.
‚úÖ After Le Fort I fracture: ascending pharyngeal provides collateral flow.
üö´ Ascending pharyngeal is not a major source in intact anatomy but becomes important after transection.
ü©∏ Clinical: maintain collateral perfusion for osteotomy or fracture healing.

text: Which of the following best describes an envelope flap in oral surgery?
option1: A full-thickness flap with a vertical releasing incision
option2: A mucoperiosteal flap without vertical incisions, extended along the gingival margin
option3: A split-thickness flap used in implant surgery
explanation:
Envelope flaps are full-thickness mucoperiosteal flaps reflected along the gingival margin without vertical releasing incisions. They provide broad surgical access while maintaining a good vascular supply and minimizing postoperative scarring.

Advantages:
- Excellent access for third molar extractions and alveoloplasty.
- Faster to elevate, less postoperative pain.
- Maintains esthetics due to absence of vertical scars.

Limitations:
- May offer less visibility in posterior regions than triangular flaps.
- Increased tension during closure in some cases.

High-yield recap:
- Envelope flap: horizontal incision only.
- Triangular flap: one vertical release for enhanced access.
- Choice depends on surgical site, exposure required, and operator preference.

text: A patient presents with progressive restriction of mouth opening following trauma to the jaw several months ago. Panoramic radiograph shows calcification in the region of the masseter and temporalis muscles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Myositis ossificans (MO) is a benign ossification of muscle tissue, often developing after trauma or repeated injury. When involving masticatory muscles‚Äîespecially the masseter, temporalis, or medial pterygoid‚Äîit may clinically mimic TMJ ankylosis.

Pathophysiology:
- Trauma triggers fibroblastic proliferation and metaplastic bone formation within muscle fibers.
- Leads to progressive limitation in mouth opening and localized tenderness.

Diagnosis:
- Radiographs/CT show irregular calcifications outside the joint capsule (distinguishing from TMJ ankylosis).

Management:
- Conservative therapy: physiotherapy, NSAIDs, and muscle relaxants.
- Surgical excision for mature ossified masses that restrict function.
- Post-op physiotherapy prevents recurrence.

High-yield recap:
- MO limits opening but occurs outside TMJ.
- Most common in masseter and medial pterygoid.
- History of trauma or prior surgery is typical.

text: Which major vessel lies in close proximity to the tonsillar fossa and is most at risk during tonsillectomy?
explanation:
Tonsillectomy ‚Äî Surgical Anatomy and Vessel at Risk

The internal carotid artery runs approximately 2‚Äì2.5 cm posterolateral to the tonsillar fossa (deep to the superior constrictor). Although injury is rare, deep or misdirected dissection beyond the tonsillar capsule and superior constrictor can jeopardize this vessel and lead to catastrophic hemorrhage.

Other relevant structures:
- Facial artery (tonsillar branch is a primary supplier of the palatine tonsil and a common source of operative bleeding).
- Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) coursing in the tonsillar bed; traction may cause dysesthesia or loss of taste to the posterior third of the tongue.

High-yield recap:
- Vessel in dangerous proximity: Internal carotid artery.
- Common bleeding source intraoperatively: tonsillar branch of the facial artery.
- Stay on the tonsillar capsule to avoid deep plane violation.

text: What is the primary use of the Cryer elevator in oral surgery?
option2: Elevation of teeth with intact roots
option3: Removal of broken roots or root fragments
explanation:
The Cryer elevator (also called the East‚ÄìWest elevator) is a triangular-bladed, heavy-duty elevator used primarily for the removal of broken or residual roots of mandibular molars, particularly when one root remains after sectioning.

üîπ Design & Mechanics:
- Triangular working end with right- and left-angled shanks.
- Sharp tip engages the cementoenamel junction or root surface.
- Uses the alveolar bone or interradicular septum as a fulcrum to lever the root from the socket.

üîπ Typical use case:
- Most useful for mandibular molars after sectioning.
- One root is removed; the Cryer engages the socket of the removed root to elevate the remaining one.

üîπ Technique tips:
- Apply controlled force to avoid alveolar fracture.
- Stabilize the mandible with opposite hand support.

Incorrect options:
- A: Straight elevators are used for anterior teeth.
- B: Cryers are not for intact roots.
- D: Maxillary elevators are used for upper molars.

High-yield recap:
- Cryer = triangular elevator for mandibular molar root fragments.
- Works on lever principle using interradicular bone as fulcrum.
- Typically used in pairs (left and right).

text: Which of the following soft-tissue injuries is best described as a tear in the tissue resulting in irregular wound margins and partial thickness involvement of the mucosa or skin?
explanation:
Laceration is a tear in soft tissue that extends through the mucosa or skin into deeper connective tissue layers. It typically results from sharp or blunt trauma and produces irregular wound margins with moderate bleeding.

Management involves:
1. Hemostasis
2. Irrigation with saline
3. Debridement of devitalized tissue
4. Primary closure within 24 hours to minimize scarring and infection

By contrast:
- Abrasion: superficial epithelial loss due to friction
- Contusion: submucosal bleeding without epithelial break
- Avulsion: complete tearing away of a tissue segment

High-yield point: Always irrigate and remove foreign debris to prevent tattooing and infection.

text: A 24-year-old patient suffers a motorcycle accident. On examination, the chin skin and subcutaneous tissue are separated from the underlying fascia, exposing bone. Which of the following terms best describes this injury?
explanation:
A degloving injury is a severe form of avulsion where the skin and subcutaneous tissue are sheared away from the underlying muscle or bone, resembling the removal of a glove.

Common sites: chin, lower lip, mandibular border.
Mechanism: shearing or crushing forces, typically from motor vehicle accidents.

Management:
- Assess flap viability (color, capillary refill)
- Debride necrotic tissue but preserve viable areas
- Reapproximate and suture if vascular supply is adequate
- If devitalized: reconstruct using local or free flap
- Broad-spectrum antibiotics + tetanus prophylaxis

Key distinction: All degloving injuries are avulsions, but not all avulsions are degloving injuries. Degloving implies layer separation and extensive undermining.

text: Following facial trauma, a patient presents with an abrasion on the cheek, a hematoma on the lip, and a jagged tear of the oral commissure. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing the soft-tissue wounds?
option3: Irrigate and debride all wounds before closure
option4: Compress the hematoma and delay treatment
explanation:
The first step in soft-tissue trauma management is irrigation and debridement to remove foreign material, necrotic debris, and bacteria. Only after the wound is clean and viable should primary closure be performed.

Subsequent steps include:
- Hemostasis (pressure, cautery)
- Layered closure with minimal tension
- Antibiotic coverage for contaminated wounds
- Follow-up for infection or scar revision

High-yield recap: Clean ‚Üí Debride ‚Üí Close. Never close a contaminated wound immediately.

text: A 14-year-old patient presents with delayed eruption of a mandibular second premolar. The tooth is submerged below the occlusal plane and produces a hollow sound on percussion. Which of the following best describes this condition?
explanation:
Dental ankylosis refers to the fusion of cementum or dentin with the surrounding alveolar bone, eliminating the normal periodontal ligament space. This leads to infraocclusion (tooth appears sunken) and a metallic or hollow sound on percussion.

Etiology:
- Trauma during eruption (most common cause)
- Local infection or inflammation
- Replantation or luxation injuries
- Genetic predisposition

Clinical features:
- Tooth immobile and infraoccluded
- Lacks physiological mobility
- Adjacent teeth continue to erupt normally
- In growing patients, bone continues to develop while ankylosed tooth remains fixed ‚Üí asymmetric occlusion

Radiographic findings:
- Absence of PDL space
- Direct continuity between root and bone

Management:
- Observe if primary tooth close to exfoliation
- Surgical luxation or extraction if causing occlusal interference
- Orthodontic or prosthetic correction afterward

High-yield recap:
‚úÖ Root fused to bone (no PDL)
‚úÖ Infraocclusion and metallic percussion sound
‚úÖ Often follows trauma in erupting teeth

text: Which radiographic projection is most useful for evaluating the maxillary sinuses and orbital floor fractures?
explanation:
Waters view (Occipitomental view) is taken with the patient's chin elevated so the orbitomeatal line forms a 37¬∞ angle with the film.

Primary indication: Evaluation of maxillary sinuses and orbital floor fractures.

Structures visualized:
- Maxillary sinuses
- Frontal sinuses
- Nasal cavity
- Orbits

Clinical use: Detects sinusitis, air-fluid levels, and orbital blowout fractures.

High-yield tip: Air-fluid levels in the maxillary sinus after trauma suggest an orbital blowout fracture.

text: Which projection is most indicated for evaluating zygomatic arch fractures?
explanation:
The Submentovertex (SMV) view captures the skull base from below and provides excellent visualization of zygomatic arches.

Indications:
- Zygomatic arch fractures
- Sphenoid sinuses
- Base of skull
- Condylar position

Radiographic appearance: In zygomatic arch fractures, one arch appears flattened or foreshortened compared to the contralateral side.

High-yield: Best view for evaluating bilateral zygomatic arches in trauma cases.

text: Which of the following structures is best evaluated using the lateral oblique projection?
explanation:
The lateral oblique view visualizes the ramus, body, and angle of the mandible on one side.

Indications:
- Fractures of the ramus, angle, and condyle
- Localized pathology (when panoramic unavailable)

Limitations:
Not ideal for symphysis or midline fractures (better seen on occlusal or PA mandible view).

Summary:
- Ramus/condyle ‚Üí Lateral oblique
- Maxillary sinus/orbit ‚Üí Waters
- Zygomatic arch ‚Üí SMV
- Condylar neck ‚Üí Reverse Towne

text: The Reverse Towne projection is most helpful for evaluating which structure?
explanation:
The Reverse Towne view (posteroanterior with mouth open) projects the condyles below the articular eminence and shows the condylar neck clearly.

Indications:
- Condylar neck fractures
- Condylar head displacement

Technique:
Patient opens mouth and tilts head downward so the condyles move below the zygomatic arches for visualization.

Mnemonic: ‚ÄúTowne looks down‚Äù ‚Üí Used when evaluating condylar fractures with the mouth open.

text: Which area of the oral cavity is most likely to show the poorest osseointegration of a dental implant?
explanation:
Explanation:

Osseointegration depends on bone density, cortical thickness, vascularity, and loading at the site. The posterior maxilla typically exhibits D4 bone (very thin cortical plate with sparse trabecular bone), which provides the least favorable conditions for primary stability and long‚Äëterm bone‚Äìimplant contact. Sinus proximity may also limit bone height.

Bone density overview (Lekholm & Zarb):
‚Ä¢ D1 ‚Äî Dense cortical bone (classically anterior mandible): excellent primary stability due to high hardness/density.
‚Ä¢ D2 ‚Äî Thick cortical with dense trabecular core (often posterior mandible): favorable balance of strength and vascularity.
‚Ä¢ D3 ‚Äî Thin cortical with dense trabecular bone (often anterior maxilla): better vascularity but less mechanical retention.
‚Ä¢ D4 ‚Äî Very thin cortical, sparse trabecular bone (often posterior maxilla): poorest osseointegration potential.

Clinical nuance: While D1 bone yields the best primary stability, some have argued that its lower vascularity could slightly slow secondary (biologic) stability compared with D2; most studies show any difference is statistically insignificant in routine practice.

Key point: Expect the posterior maxilla (D4) to have the worst osseointegration prognosis compared with other regions.

text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for dental implant placement?
option2: History of recent head and neck radiation therapy
explanation:
Explanation:

Chronological advanced age alone is not a contraindication to implant therapy. Success is driven by systemic stability, bone quality, oral hygiene, and maintenance, not the patient‚Äôs numerical age. Older adults can achieve outcomes comparable to younger cohorts when these factors are optimized.

True (absolute/relative) contraindications & risk factors:
‚Ä¢ Uncontrolled systemic disease (e.g., poorly controlled diabetes, bleeding disorders, significant immunosuppression).
‚Ä¢ Recent head & neck radiation (especially high doses within the past year) due to impaired vascularity and risk of osteoradionecrosis.
‚Ä¢ Active IV antiresorptives (e.g., IV bisphosphonates) with risk of MRONJ.
‚Ä¢ Untreated periodontitis, poor plaque control, and tobacco use increase complication risk (relative).

High‚Äëyield recap:
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Not a contraindication: advanced age by itself.
‚Ä¢ ‚ùå Potential contraindications: uncontrolled disease, recent high‚Äëdose radiation, IV antiresorptives, uncontrolled periodontal infection.
‚Ä¢ Focus on biologic age, systemic stability, and site quality rather than calendar age when planning implants.

text: Which of the following statements regarding screw-retained versus cement-retained implant restorations is most accurate?
option1: Cement-retained crowns provide easier retrievability than screw-retained crowns
option2: Screw-retained crowns have a higher risk of peri-implantitis from residual cement
option3: Cement-retained crowns minimize occlusal access hole complications
option4: Screw-retained crowns cannot achieve good esthetics in the anterior region
explanation:
Explanation:

Implant restorations can be attached to the abutment by either screw retention or cement retention. Selection depends on esthetics, retrievability, implant angulation, and hygiene maintenance.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Screw-retained restorations
‚Ä¢ Mechanically fastened via an access screw through the crown.
‚Ä¢ Advantages: easy retrievability for maintenance/repair; no risk of cement-induced peri-implantitis; predictable seating.
‚Ä¢ Disadvantages: visible access hole can compromise esthetics (especially anterior); technique sensitive; possible screw loosening/fracture.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Cement-retained restorations
‚Ä¢ Cemented to the abutment like conventional crowns.
‚Ä¢ Advantages: superior esthetics (no occlusal access hole), passive fit often easier, reduced screw fatigue.
‚Ä¢ Disadvantages: risk of residual cement causing peri-implantitis, difficult retrievability, subgingival cement challenges‚Äîespecially with deep margins.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Clinical guidelines
‚Ä¢ Prefer screw-retained when retrievability and hygiene are priorities (posterior units, full-arch, high peri-implantitis risk).
‚Ä¢ Prefer cement-retained in high-esthetic zones when angulation is ideal and margins are accessible for thorough cement cleanup.

High‚ÄëYield Recap:
‚Ä¢ Screw-retained ‚Üí retrievable & hygienic; esthetic limitation is the access hole.
‚Ä¢ Cement-retained ‚Üí better esthetics; main risk is residual cement and harder retrieval.
‚Ä¢ Correct choice: Cement-retained crowns minimize occlusal access hole complications.

text: Following tooth extraction, which of the following best describes the pattern and timing of alveolar bone resorption?
option1: Most bone resorption occurs after 1 year and affects the lingual plate more than the buccal
option2: Most bone resorption occurs within the first 3 months, predominantly affecting the buccal plate
option3: Vertical bone loss predominates in the first 3 months, followed by horizontal resorption
option4: Bone resorption occurs evenly on buccal and lingual surfaces over time
explanation:
Alveolar Bone Resorption After Tooth Extraction

After tooth extraction, most bone resorption occurs within the first 3 months, mainly affecting the buccal plate. The buccal cortical plate is thinner and has less blood supply, making it more prone to collapse. Ridge remodeling leads to narrowing and lingual shift of the alveolar ridge. Proper grafting techniques help preserve ridge width.
  • Pattern: Buccal > Lingual > Vertical
  • Timeline: Most loss in first 3 months
  • Clinical Tip: Consider socket preservation for implants or prosthetics.

text: Which of the following is the most common indication for performing a tonsillectomy?
option1: Recurrent or chronic tonsillitis causing airway obstruction or infection
option2: Presence of small, non-inflamed tonsils without symptoms
option3: Pain during swallowing due to dental caries
option4: Mild tonsillar hypertrophy without recurrent infection
explanation:
Tonsillectomy ‚Äì Indications, Procedure, and Complications

Performed primarily for recurrent or chronic tonsillitis or airway obstruction from hypertrophy. Other indications include peritonsillar abscess recurrence or suspicion of malignancy. Postoperative hemorrhage is the most common complication.
  • Indications: ‚â•7 episodes/year or ‚â•5 per year for 2 years.
  • Complication: Secondary hemorrhage (5‚Äì10 days postop).

text: What is the minimum interocclusal (vertical) space required for a single implant-supported crown?
explanation:
Interocclusal Space Requirements for Implant Restorations

Proper vertical space is essential for implant prosthetics. A single implant crown requires about 7‚Äì8 mm from bone crest to opposing occlusal surface.
  • Single crown: 7‚Äì8 mm
  • Overdenture: 10‚Äì12 mm
  • Full-arch: 12‚Äì15 mm
Insufficient space can lead to overcontoured restorations, poor hygiene, or prosthetic complications.

text: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of microgrooved and roughened implant surfaces compared to machined (smooth) implants?
option1: They reduce bone contact to prevent implant overloading
option2: They enhance osseointegration by increasing surface area for bone attachment
option3: They are primarily used to prevent soft tissue proliferation along the implant collar
option4: They delay healing to allow for gradual fibrous encapsulation
explanation:
Implant Surface Types and Their Role in Osseointegration

Modern implants use roughened or microgrooved surfaces (SLA, RBM, anodized, HA-coated) to increase surface area and enhance bone-to-implant contact (BIC). This leads to faster and stronger osseointegration.
  • Machined (smooth): Slower healing, fibrous tissue risk.
  • Roughened: Faster bone apposition, shorter healing (6‚Äì8 weeks).
  • Coated: Hydroxyapatite or CaP coatings improve biocompatibility.

text: Which of the following nerves are anesthetized by a Gow-Gates mandibular nerve block?
option1: Inferior alveolar, lingual, buccal, mylohyoid, and auriculotemporal nerves
option2: Inferior alveolar and lingual nerves only
option3: Buccal, mental, and incisive nerves only
explanation:
Gow-Gates Mandibular Nerve Block

Provides anesthesia to nearly the entire mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve. Injection is made at the neck of the mandibular condyle.
  • Nerves blocked: Inferior alveolar, lingual, mylohyoid, buccal, auriculotemporal.
  • Advantages: Wide anesthesia, less vascular risk.
  • Disadvantages: Slower onset (5‚Äì10 min).

text: A patient presents with swelling and trismus from an infected mandibular third molar. Which fascial space is most likely involved first?
explanation:
Fascial Space Infections from Mandibular Molars

Mandibular third molar roots lie below the mylohyoid line, so infection spreads into the submandibular space. First molar infections (above the line) spread to the sublingual space.
  • Third molar ‚Üí Submandibular space
  • First molar ‚Üí Sublingual space
  • Severe bilateral infection ‚Üí Ludwig‚Äôs angina (airway emergency)

text: Which of the following statements best describes osteomyelitis of the jaws?
option1: It is more common in the maxilla due to its dense cortical bone and limited blood supply
option2: It primarily affects the mandible and involves inflammation and necrosis of bone marrow spaces
option3: It develops rapidly but resolves without antibiotic therapy
option4: It is limited to cortical bone without involvement of the medullary spaces
explanation:
Osteomyelitis of the Jaws

Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone and marrow spaces, most often in the mandible due to poor vascularity. It leads to necrosis, sequestrum formation, and chronic infection.
  • Acute: Pain, fever, swelling, paresthesia.
  • Chronic: Sinus tracts, sequestra, sclerosis.
  • Radiographic: Moth-eaten or mixed radiolucent-radiopaque pattern.
  • Treatment: Debridement + long-term antibiotics ¬± hyperbaric oxygen.

text: During emergence from anesthesia, a patient develops airway obstruction with stridor and paradoxical breathing. What is the best immediate management?
option2: Administer succinylcholine and provide positive pressure ventilation
explanation:
Laryngospasm ‚Äì Airway Emergency During Anesthesia

Laryngospasm is reflex closure of the vocal cords causing airway obstruction. Management includes clearing the airway, positive pressure O‚ÇÇ, and succinylcholine (0.1‚Äì0.5 mg/kg IV) if persistent.
High-Yield Summary:
  • Respiratory Depression: Naloxone, Flumazenil
  • Laryngospasm: Succinylcholine
  • Bronchospasm: Albuterol or Epinephrine
  • Laryngeal Edema / Anaphylaxis: Epinephrine
  • Bradycardia / Hypotension: Atropine, Ephedrine, or Phenylephrine
  • Angina / MI: Nitroglycerin, Morphine, or Aspirin
